an airplane-and specimens of Grecian art. The examples of art have
been placed in glass exhibits on the

versities of Germany through measures which have
struck at principles we believe to be fundamental to
universities throughout the world." (Italics ours.)
Clearly the central theme here is the cultural degradation of Germany which has gone hand in hand with the
Nazi doctrine. As such the Crimson's statement of the
problem was fundamentally incorrectly. But proceeding
even further and analyzing the paper's contention that
Germany today is one of the greatest cultural centers
in the world, we find ourselves again totally unable to
agree. Traditional German culture reigned supreme,
yes; but, according to men whose observations we respect, this heritage with its attendant freedom and individuality has been disowned by the present regime and
replaced by a system the chief characteristic of which is
absolute regimentation of the mind.
The following description of student life in Germany
at the present time should suffice to commend President
Conant's stand and discredit the assertions of the
Crimson. It was penned by Oswald Garrison Villard,
editor of The Nation, who has been observing the destinies of Hitlerism from its inception. He concurs with
many others in writing:

Little Man-What Now?
Youth's Challenge To The
"Middle-Aged" Social Order

Open Houses
Beginning on Thursday, November
9, 1934, a period of allotted open
houses shall exist, on which days the
designated fraternities shall be permitted to entertain men in their first
year of residence, provided that said
entertainment shall be restricted to
said fraternity house. On such allotted days the designated fraternities shall enjoy priority over all other
fraternities, but in the event that two
fraternities shall share the same day
and each shall extend an invitation
to the same rushee, the decision shall
rest with the latter. Specified open
house days shall last from 8 a. m.
until 1 a. m., the following morning.
All invitations for the open houses
must be written to the freshmen and
must be in the hands of the President
of the Board on Monday, November 5,
1934, and they should be in the boxes
before 10 a. m., November 6.

Spokesman To Be Chosen
1. If more than one fraternity be
represented at the residence of the
rushee, a spokesman for the group
shall be chosen. At 3.00 he shall inform the rushee what fraternities are
present and then ask the rushee if
he has arrived at a decision.
2. If the rushee has not reached a
decision, he shall state the fraternities which he has under consideration.
These fraternities shall draw lots for
dates with the rushee; said dates not
to be more than one hour in duration.

son claimed. Coins, bronze dishes,
arms, rings, lamps, pins, surgical instruments, etc., were some of the
articles, indicators of a past civilization, which were uncovered.
Over
1,000 masks and figurines which illustrate the history of Greek Art of
the sixth and fifth centuries, B. C.,
were brought to light by findings at
Olynthus.
A manuscript containing a treaty
made between Philip of Macedon and
the city of Olynthus was discovered.
Philip broke this compact, which
guaranteed the safety and security of
the city, when he crushed Olynthus.
Demonthenes wrote three orations in
an attempt to save the city.
The expedition discovered many
types of graves while digging up the
ruins. Coins fare for Charon, boatman
of the Styx, were found in the graves.
A collection of twenty-six skeletons
found together, showed than an epidemic probably struck the city at
some time.
A Greek Classical City
Olynthus, only Greek classical city
of the fifth and fourth centuries, was
destroyed by Philip of Macedon in 348
B. C. The time when Olynthus thrived
was the best period of Greek art,
many noted men have said. An expedition of the Johns Hopkins University first identified their find as Olynthus in 1928. The group returned in
1931 for further excavations.
Dr. Robinson traveled from Rome
to Pompeii and then to Berlin. In
Germany's capital he delivered two
lectures in German concerning his archaeological work. When Dr. Robinson mentioned some swastika signs
found on a few mosaics, the audience
burst into wild acclaim for their nanational emblem. The Archaeology Institute of the German Empire honored
him with a membership.
Dr. Robinson also visited Copenhagen, Oslo, Oxford, and Paris on his
journey.

pointed to the possibility of rain interfering with the seventh and allimportant game between the Detroit

Navin Field. The weather man predicted "showery weather."
The personnel of the Detroit battery for the final battle is just about
as uncertain as the weather conditions. Schoolboy Rowe, slated to do
the "iron-man" act, emerged from
yesterday's game with the back of
He
his right hand badly swollen.
seems definitely out of the picture.
Either Tom Bridges, Elden Auker, or
General Crowder will get the call,
with the former being favored.
Frankie Frisch announced this
morning that in all probability Dizzy
at
Dean would take his third crack
the Tigers today. Although the Card
manager did not commit himself definitely, it was believed that Dizzy
would get the nod over Bill Hallahan.

Clearly the central theme here is the cultural degradation of Germany which has gone hand in hand with the
Nazi doctrine. As such the Crimson's statement of the
problem was fundamentally incorrectly. But proceeding
even further and analyzing the paper's contention that
Germany today is one of the greatest cultural centers
in the world, we find ourselves again totally unable to
agree. Traditional German culture reigned supreme,
yes; but, according to men whose observations we respect, this heritage with its attendant freedom and individuality has been disowned by the present regime and
replaced by a system the chief characteristic of which is
absolute regimentation of the mind.
The following description of student life in Germany
at the present time should suffice to commend President
Conant's stand and discredit the assertions of the
Crimson. It was penned by Oswald Garrison Villard,
editor of The Nation, who has been observing the destinies of Hitlerism from its inception. He concurs with
many others in writing:

articles, indicators of a past civilization, which were uncovered.
Over
1,000 masks and figurines which illustrate the history of Greek Art of
the sixth and fifth centuries, B. C.,
were brought to light by findings at
Olynthus.
A manuscript containing a treaty
made between Philip of Macedon and
the city of Olynthus was discovered.
Philip broke this compact, which
guaranteed the safety and security of
the city, when he crushed Olynthus.
Demonthenes wrote three orations in
an attempt to save the city.
The expedition discovered many
types of graves while digging up the
ruins. Coins fare for Charon, boatman
of the Styx, were found in the graves.
A collection of twenty-six skeletons
found together, showed than an epidemic probably struck the city at
some time.
A Greek Classical City
Olynthus, only Greek classical city
of the fifth and fourth centuries, was
destroyed by Philip of Macedon in 348
B. C. The time when Olynthus thrived
was the best period of Greek art,
many noted men have said. An expedition of the Johns Hopkins University first identified their find as Olynthus in 1928. The group returned in
1931 for further excavations.
Dr. Robinson traveled from Rome
to Pompeii and then to Berlin. In
Germany's capital he delivered two
lectures in German concerning his archaeological work. When Dr. Robinson mentioned some swastika signs
found on a few mosaics, the audience
burst into wild acclaim for their nanational emblem. The Archaeology Institute of the German Empire honored
him with a membership.
Dr. Robinson also visited Copenhagen, Oslo, Oxford, and Paris on his
journey.

Indications early this morning

as uncertain as the weather conditions. Schoolboy Rowe, slated to do
the "iron-man" act, emerged from
yesterday's game with the back of
He
his right hand badly swollen.
seems definitely out of the picture.

General Crowder will get the call,
with the former being favored.

morning that in all probability Dizzy
at
Dean would take his third crack
the Tigers today. Although the Card
manager did not commit himself definitely, it was believed that Dizzy
would get the nod over Bill Hallahan.
